posts.cooked: I have been experimenting with utilizing cOPRs from the TBA platform, specifically the Blue Alliance site for FIRST Robotics Competition event data, to develop match prediction models, akin to approaches discussed in this older post (though my model differs in being a simpler binary predictor). I believe that trained models may more effectively capture the nuanced relationships between alliance members and event dynamics compared to purely algebraic models. For example, two robots filling L4 together might end up occupying both L4 and L3 spots. While creating such scenarios manually could be time-consuming, I wonder if there’s an efficient method to access historical TBA data directly from events. Unless I’m mistaken, using cOPRs prior to each match could help assess the realism of early match inaccuracies. If not, I’d like to understand how TBA computes OPRs. Additionally, considering that alliance scoring data can be retrieved via their API, is it feasible to replicate the calculation of OPRs as detailed here? I’ve briefly checked their repository but haven’t found relevant information yet. Any further insights would be valuable, especially given my limited experience in statistics and Python. Currently, my model uses LightGBM with various parameters optimized through grid search and hyperparameter tuning, alongside attempts at custom neural networks, though those proved slower and marginally less accurate.

link_counts.title: The Math Behind OPR — An Introduction – The Blue Alliance Blog

posts.name: Auxiliatrix
posts.cooked: Oh wow, this takes me back. I’d recommend reaching out to Eugene Fang from 604; he’s still very active in the FIRST community.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Using cOPRs from before each match shows realistic inaccuracies in early matches. Frankly speaking, (c)OPRs are not gonna be a great predictor for the first 75% or more of quals. An EPA model that accounts for limited scoring locations or game-pieces is likely to perform better for your applications. Time series data with interdependencies and changing variance is challenging to work with in machine learning—it’s not impossible, but other tools often perform better than basic ML algorithms. I put together a cascading model for limited scoring locations/gampieces for the 2025 game component EPA, I can elaborate on that if there is interest.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: This document contains a screenshot named "Screenshot_20250529_232346_Chrome", captured at 1080×561 pixels with a file size of 113 KB. The image was also available in optimized versions: one at 690x358 pixels and another at 1035x537 pixels with enhanced quality. Additionally, Welcome back!

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked: Is there an easy way to access historical TBA data from the same event? I am nearly 100% confident that the match-by-match evolution of cOPR calculated by TBA for an event is not saved. Unless I am misunderstanding something, using cOPRs from before each match should show realistic inaccuracies in early matches. If not, how are the TBA cOPRs calculated? Any other insights would also be helpful, since I am neither a statistics nor a Python expert. Why are you trying to improve match predictions? Are you looking for a tangible benefit or are you just pursuing an academic exercise? To the extent match prediction has value, what additional value would you expect to gain over something like the readily available Statbotics match predictions?

posts.name: Justin Tervay
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned version:

TBA cOPR code is used here: https://github.com/the-blue-alliance/the-blue-alliance/blob/e5aa155f9cac5731db167d0d20806b7be82de0d3/src/backend/common/helpers/matchstats_helper.py

We build components similarly to regular OP, but instead of total scores, we use the component values.

posts.name: Gabriel Krotkov (he/him)
posts.cooked:
Is there an easy way to access historical TBA data from the same event?  

I maintain a package called scoutR with a function that computes OPR progression over the course of an event. If you're new to R, check out my introduction. The documentation is still pending further updates.  

This code returns a dataframe for the 2025 CHS Glen Allen district event with 36 columns and 51 rows.  

Here's an example:  
event_opr_progression("2025vagle", response_name = "autoCoralCount")  

Below is a screenshot of the results:

link_counts.title: FRC Scouting Aide for R Users • scoutR

posts.cooked:
Why are you trying to improve match predictions? Are you looking for a tangible benefit or are you just pursuing an academic exercise?

The primary purpose for my project was to learn more about machine learning; making something that could be useful would be nice, but I wanted to learn more about different types of neural networks and how to create/use them.

With the models that I’ve made, I think I have a better (albeit basic) understanding of them, and I was interested in seeing how accurate of a model I could make. Although, from what @Skyehawk said, if accuracy is what I want, then there are better ways to approach the problem.

If you have the time, I would definitely like to see how you decided to implement this, even if it isn’t necessarily an improvement.

This seems almost exactly like what I was looking for. I haven’t ever used R (and I also have many more side-project ideas now), but if I ever come back to this I will definitely look into it.

Thanks for all the help, everyone!

posts.name: Eugene Fang
posts.cooked: That’s the match prediction code which is hidden by default. The match prediction code also uses a slightly different version of OPR, Offense Power Rating, Calculated Contribution that has been shown experimentally to be more stable with fewer matches played. This is only used for match predictions, not for the cO PRs displayed on the event insights tab or available via the API.
